content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Having a very clear description and being a fun and simple clash to, I really enjoyed solving this on my own. Congrats, friend! This post will be its last one after approval.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun visual challenge :)

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Perfect difficulty level for CoC IMO, it took me about 4 minutes.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Goal
* Please use <<bold>> instead of [[variable]] format for emphasis.

* Please explain the rule in determining the size of the hole here.

* Please explain when {{Cannot draw donut}} should be output here.

Input
* Please rewrite the whole section as follows:

<<Line 1>>: Two space-separated integers [[donutSize]] and [[holeSize]] for the size (height and length) of the donut and the size of the hole respectively.

Output
* Please rewrite the whole section as follows:

<<[[donutSize]] lines>>: The donut
or
<<1 line>>: {{Cannot draw donut}}

Constraints
* Please rewrite the whole section as follows:
1 â‰¤ [[donutSize]], [[holeSize]] â‰¤ 20

Thanks.

Okay, thanks! This is my first time doing clash of code so I might make some mistakes. But I have a question about the output advice. Shouldn't I make it clear that the hole should be in the middle of the donut?
thanks ;) I was wondering if it wouldn be too heavy
just wanted to introduce something fresher than clashes like: 'if input is in this range, print this message, else check in other range' :)
yayyyy my first contribution approved!
You should. But do that in Goal section, where explanations of the task should be located.
i don't know... i tried my best... what do u think now about Goal section?

Goal section looks good to me. This part "this condition cannot be met" may be a bit unclear; I assume you're referring to cases like Test 2 and Validator 2, where the hole overlaps with the donut's outer edge. Maybe you can mention that instead?

Constraints
* You should also add that
If the donut is valid, [[donutSize]] - [[holeSize]] is an even number.

Now the cases - some suggestions to improve the similarity and scenario coverage:

* Test 3 isn't similar to Validator 3. Please change Validator 3 so that [[donutSize]] < [[holeSize]] there too, and then create a new pair of cases where [[donutSize]] = [[holeSize]].

* Add a new pair of cases where [[donutSize]] â‰¥ 10 and [[holeSize]] = [[donutSize]] - 2.

* Add a new pair of cases where [[donutSize]] â‰¥ 10 and [[holeSize]] = 2.

Thanks.

the 2 of your proposal pairs are very similar so i think only one more test would be enough. I'm skeptical of the advice: If the donut is valid, [[donutSize]] - [[holeSize]] is an even number. I think it might be an additional challenge for users to discover this!

1. I don't understand how the proposed pairs are similar.

2. I disagree. If you don't specify that, that means there can be cases where [[donutSize]] - [[holeSize]] is odd, but it's not clear how such a case should be handled. Constraints section gives a clear signal to the players that they need not worry about having to handle such cases.

as for pairs: I simply believe that these tests will not introduce anything new and various cases have already been checked and displayed to the user. as for constraints: okay, the task may already be demanding, maybe such a tip is indeed advisable...

Thanks!

Oh, remember to add a write statement to the stub generator, e.g. "write answer" or "write donut".

Other than that, I don't have other comments for now. ðŸ™‚
really? why to add this? People will remove this part of the code anyway. I added only 'read donutSize:int holeSize:int' cuz this can be helpful and save their time
It is for beginners.

And do we know whether *every player* removes that part of the code? We don't know. We shouldn't just take it away for the benefit of the players who do so at the expense of the players who want the code. Not every programming language provides a short and simple print function like Python.

so you propose to save this short universal code, for those who have chosen a language that does not provide a quick-to-print function... I didn't look at it that way... in many clashes you can notice such a code appearing, so maybe for some reason... Okay, I guess I can agree to that.
I'm saying it's both for beginners and for anyone who wants the code. Don't take such code away from them.
Okay, so to sum up today's entire conversation, thank you very much for your effort and in-depth help! You guided me in making my first ever clash! Until next time :)
You're welcome!
